Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

Jeremy Barnum (CFO)

reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)

reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: I would point out that this outlook still embeds significant reprice lags: we think a more sustainable NII ex. Markets run-rate in the medium-term is well below this quarter's $84 billion, as well as below the $80 billion that is implied for the rest of the year by our full year guidance; and while we don't know exactly when this lower run-rate will be reached, when it happens, we believe it will be around the mid-70s.
reference:

JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: And, of course, as we mentioned last quarter, this NII outlook remains highly sensitive to the uncertainty associated with the timing and the extent of deposit reprice, investment portfolio decisions, the dynamics of QT and RRP, the trajectory of Fed funds, as well as the broader macroeconomic environment – including its impact on loan growth.

Ken Usdin (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: Do you think it's more just because inflation's coming down? Do you think it's because the Fed's just got to react to an even tougher economy and still some of those storm clouds that might be out there?
reference:
Ken Usdin (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: Just kind of your general thinking about the other read-throughs of what lower rates quicker will mean for the broader economy.
reference:
Ken Usdin (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: Well first of all, I don't quite believe it.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: So the Fed has the rate curve, the forward short-term rate curve, almost at 1% higher than what the market has.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: So one of the things you got to always prepare for is – it could be anything, we don't know what the rate curve is going to be in a year. And so we're quite cautious in that and quite thoughtful about that.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: Obviously, the short-term read is higher recessionary risk and then inflation coming down.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: So I think inflation will come down a little bit, but it could easily be stickier than people think and therefore, the rate curve will have to go up a little bit.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: Okay. Thank you very much.
reference:
Ken Usdin (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: Thank you. The next question comes from the line of John McDonald with Autonomous Research. You may proceed.
reference:
Operator (Host)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: Hi, thanks. Jeremy, wanted to follow up again on the drivers of the NII revision and the lower rates paid assumption.
reference:
John McDonald (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: You mentioned the Fed cuts coming sooner and positive feedback on the customer offers.
reference:
John McDonald (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: What about the March events? Do the bank failures there that happened in March – in your view, do they slow the reprice intensity because folks are moving other than price reasons?
reference:
John McDonald (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: Or they intensify it industry-wide because smaller banks have to reprice to keep their deposits? How do those events influence your view of the reprice?
reference:
John McDonald (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: Yeah. John, it's a really good question, and we've obviously thought about that.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: But as we sit here today, I guess I have two answers to that.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: One is it's not meaningfully affecting our current outlook – we don't see it as a major driver.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: And I think in terms of the larger dynamics that you lay out, it's just a little too early to tell. But from where we are right now, the base case is no real impact.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: Okay. And then I wanted to ask Jamie – there's a narrative out there that the industry could see a credit crunch – banks are going to stop lending, even Jay Powell mentioned that as a risk.
reference:
John McDonald (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: Do you see that in terms of anything you look at in terms of lending and is that a reaction that makes sense – that banks might be retrenching a lot here? Do you worry about that for the economy in terms of credit crunch? Thanks.
reference:
John McDonald (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: Yeah. I wouldn't use the word credit crunch if I were you.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: Obviously, there's going to be a little bit of tightening, and most of that will be around certain real estate things.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: And you've heard it from real estate investors already, so I just look at that as a kind of thumb on the scale.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: It just makes the Fed's conditions be a little bit tighter, it increases the odds of a recession – that's what that is. It's not like a credit crunch.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: Thank you. Our next question comes from Erika Najarian with UBS. You may proceed.
reference:
Operator (Host)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: Hi. Good morning. My first question is you mentioned that your reserve build was driven mostly by worse economic assumptions.
reference:
Erika Najarian (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: I'm wondering if you could update us on what unemployment rate you're assuming in your reserve.
reference:
Erika Najarian (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: Yeah. So, Erika, as you know, we take – not going to go into a lot of detail here – but we take the outlook from our economists, we run a bunch of different scenarios and we probability-weight those.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: The central case outlook from our research team hasn't actually changed, but we felt that in line with what Jamie just said in terms of a little bit of tightening as a result of the events of March, it made sense to add a little bit of weight to our relative adverse case.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: So we did that, which changed the weighted-average expectation. And I think that the weighted-average peak unemployment that we're using now is something like 5.8%.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: So, as you think about all of what you've just told us – so $81 billion of NII this year, and who knows when medium-term is going to happen of mid-70s, the clear strength of the franchise producing 23% ROTCE in a quarter where your CET1 is 13.8% and a reserve that already reflects 5.8% unemployment.
reference:
Erika Najarian (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: As we think about recession and what JPMorgan can earn in a recession, do you think you can hit 17% ROTCE even in 2024 – assuming we do have a recession in 2024 as everybody is expecting – given all these revenue dynamics and how prepared you are on the reserve?
reference:
Erika Najarian (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: Yeah. I mean that's an interesting question, Erika. I guess I'll say a couple things.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: It's a great question, so I want to see how Jeremy answers it.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: Okay. Let's take a crack. Let's see what the boss thinks.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: I think number one, we believe, have said, and continue to believe that this is fundamentally a 17% through the cycle ROTCE franchise, so number one.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: Number two, as Jamie always says, we run this company for all different scenarios and to have it be as resilient as possible across all different scenarios.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: On the particular question of ROTCE expectations in 2024 contingent on the particular economic outlook, obviously it depends a lot on the nature of the recession.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: I think we feel really good about how the company is positioned for a recession, but we're a bank.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: A very serious recession is of course going to be a headwind for returns, but we think even in a fairly severe recession, we'll deliver very good returns – whether that's 17% or not is too much detail for now.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: Thank you.
reference:
Erika Najarian (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: The next question comes from the line of Jim Mitchell from Seaport Global Securities. You may proceed.
reference:
Operator (Host)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: Hey. Good morning. Maybe just a little bit on the deposit, your thought process there. You've seen some inflows. Why do you think that you lose them going forward?
reference:
Jim Mitchell (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: And just maybe talk a little bit about the dynamic in pricing – do you feel like given the inflows, do you see some pricing power for the larger banks?
reference:
Jim Mitchell (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: Yeah. A couple things there. So, first of all, we don't know. Right? The deposits just came in. We don't know. We're guessing.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: Number two, the deposits just came in. So, by definition, these are somewhat flighty deposits because they just came into us, so it's prudent and appropriate for us to assume that they won't be particularly stable.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: Number three, there's a natural amount of internal migration of deposits to money funds so you have to overlay that and that's embedded in our assumptions.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: And number four, it's a competitive market, and it's entirely possible that people temporarily come to us and then over time decide to go elsewhere.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: So, for all of those reasons, we're just being realistic about the stickiness of it.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: If I add, I would say, categorically, there's no pricing power that the bigger banks have because if you look at the pricing – and we look at pricing sheets all the time – every bank is in a slightly different position and every bank is competing in three-month, six-month, nine-month savings rates.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: And then you have the online banks, you got treasury bills, you got money market funds. There's no pricing power for the bank, but obviously we all have different franchises and we're all in a slightly different position.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: No, fair – all fair points. And maybe just a follow-up on John's question on the lending environment. You talked about the industry likely pulling back.
reference:
Jim Mitchell (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: Are you changing your underwriting standards in any way? Just trying to think through is there potential for some market share gains given your strength of capital and liquidity? Or how you're thinking about the loan environment?
reference:
Jim Mitchell (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: I'd say very modestly, but we look at that all the time.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: Yeah. And we always say, right, we underwrite through the cycle.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: And I think notably, we didn't loosen our underwriting standards when all the numbers looked crazy good during the pandemic, and we're not going to overreact now and tighten unreasonably.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: Some of that correction happens naturally – credit metrics deteriorate for borrowers whether in consumer or wholesale, and that might make them leave our pre-existing risk appetite, but we're not running around aggressively tightening standards right now.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: Okay. Great. Thanks.
reference:
Jim Mitchell (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: The next question comes from the line of Gerard Cassidy with RBC Capital Markets. You may proceed.
reference:
Operator (Host)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: Thank you. Hi, Jeremy.
reference:
Gerard Cassidy (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: Hey, Gerard.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: In your comments about your CET1 ratio, obviously it came in strong at 13.8%.
reference:
Gerard Cassidy (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: You've got the GSIB buffer obviously going up next year, and we have the stress test coming this summer or in June – the results – which maybe will lead to banks, including yours, having a higher Stress Capital Buffer. Where should we think about that CET1 ratio being by the end of the year, do you think?
reference:
Gerard Cassidy (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: Yeah. So a few things on there, Gerard.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: So we have previously said that we were targeting 13.5% in the first quarter of 2024 as a function of assuming an unchanged SCB, the increased GSIB step and operating with a 50-basis-point buffer.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: So, the point that Jamie made a second ago, in light of the environment, Basel IV, dry powder, you know, who knows how we'll tweak that going forward. But that's still our base case assumption.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: Specifically on the stress test, contrary to what I've heard some people argue, our ability to predict the SCB ahead of time from running our own process is actually quite limited.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: And you'll remember last year that even though we did predict an increase, we were off by almost a factor of two in terms of how big it wound up being, and that was a big surprise for the whole industry.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: So, we want to be quite humble about our ability to predict the SCB.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: But having said that, for right now we are assuming it will be unchanged. There are some tailwinds in there through the OCI, but we believe there will likely be some offsets and harsher credit shocks in the number, so for planning purposes right now we're assuming flat for SCB, and we'll know soon enough what that actual number is.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: Sure. And then just as a follow-up, if I heard you correctly, can you give us a little more color – I think you mentioned in building the loan loss reserve this quarter you identified some one-off credits?
reference:
Gerard Cassidy (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: I don't know if that's how you said it – there's some larger credits. Were they commercial real estate oriented? Were they commercial? Any more color there?
reference:
Gerard Cassidy (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: No, it wasn't commercial real estate. It was just a couple of single name items in the Corporate segment.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: Leverage loan-type items or just regular Corporate credits?
reference:
Gerard Cassidy (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: Regular Corporate credits. I'd rather not get into too much detail...
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: Okay, very good.
reference:
Gerard Cassidy (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 10

text: …Gerard. Sorry. Thanks.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 10

text: Thank you.
reference:
Gerard Cassidy (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 10

text: The next question comes from the line of Ebrahim Poonawala with Bank of America Merrill Lynch. You may proceed.
reference:
Operator (Host)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 10

text: Hi, good morning. I guess, maybe one question, Jeremy. You reminded us of the relatively low office exposure for JPM. But, obviously, you're big players in the CRE market.
reference:
Ebrahim H. Poonawala (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 10

text: Just give us a sense of when you look at the two pressure points on CRE, one, how much is oversupply – and that probably goes beyond office into apartments – how much of a issue is oversupply in the market as we think about the next few years going into a weakening economy?
reference:
Ebrahim H. Poonawala (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 10

text: And how much of a risk is higher for longer rates in that if the central banks can't cut rates in the next year or two, we will see a ton of more pain because of the re-fi wall that's coming up?
reference:
Ebrahim H. Poonawala (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 10

text: Yeah, so Ebrahim let me sort of respond narrowly in connection with our portfolio and our exposure, right?
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 10

text: So, really, the large majority of our commercial real estate exposure is multi-family lending in supply constrained markets.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 10

text: And I think it's quite important to recognize the difference between that and sort of higher end, higher price point, non-rent controlled, not supply constrained markets.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 10

text: So, our space is really quite different in that respect, and I think that's a big part of the reason the performance has been so good for so long.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 10

text: So, of course, we watch it very carefully and we don't assume that past performance predicts future results here, but I think our multi-family lending portfolio is quite low risk in the scheme of things.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 10

text: Can I just add also, housing is in short supply in America. It's not massively oversupplied like you saw in 2008.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 10

text: Yeah. And then in terms of the office space, as you know, our exposure is quite small.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 10

text: Yes, Jamie, has also mentioned all the re-fi dynamics that you mentioned too are something that the office space is processing one way or the other.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 10

text: Our office exposure is quite modest, very concentrated in Class A buildings in sort of dense urban locations where the return to the office narrative is one of the drivers – is generally in favor of high occupancy.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 10

text: So, again, watching it. There are obviously specific things here and there to pay attention to, but in the scheme of things for us, not a big issue.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 10

text: And just as a follow up, I think the other risk from higher for longer rates, I think, is this – the ability of the economy, the financial markets to sustain a 5% less Fed fund for a long period of time?
reference:
Ebrahim H. Poonawala (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 10

text: Like, what are the other areas you're watching if duration mismatch and bank balance sheets being one, CRE market being one, are you worrying – worried about non-banks that have grown exponentially over the last decade in terms of risks at the non-banks if rates don't get cut?
reference:
Ebrahim H. Poonawala (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

text: And if you can talk to the transmission mechanism of that coming back and hitting banks given the leverage that banks provide to the non-banks.
reference:
Ebrahim H. Poonawala (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

text: Yeah, so I'd like to answer that. So there is a risk of higher rates for longer.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

text: And don't just think of just the Fed Funds rate, because I think you should – for our planning – I'd be thinking more about it could be 6%.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

text: And then think about the five- and ten-year rate which could be 5%, and I think if those things happen – I'm not saying they're going to happen – I just think people should prepare for them, they saw what just happened when rates went up beyond people's expectations.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

text: You had the gilt problem in London, you had some of the banks here. People need to be prepared for the potential of higher rates for longer.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

text: If and when that happens, it will undress problems in the economy for those who are too exposed to floating rates, for those who are too exposed to re-fi risk.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

text: Those exposures will be in multiple parts of the economy. I say to all of our clients – now would be the time to fix it.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

text: Do not put yourself in a position where that risk is excessive for your company, your business, your investment pools, et cetera. That's answer number one.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

text: Number two is, it will not come back to JPMorgan. Okay? While we do provide credit to what you call shadow banks, it is very – we think – it's very, very secure.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

text: That does not mean it won't come back to other credit providers.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

text: Got it. Very helpful. Thank you.
reference:
Ebrahim H. Poonawala (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

text: The next question comes from the line of Mike Mayo with Wells Fargo Securities. You may proceed.
reference:
Operator (Host)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

text: Hey Jeremy, you mentioned a degree of reintermediation to the lending markets. You said capital markets activity has gone to bank lending, and I'm just wondering, as part of your $7 billion increased NII guide, are you assuming better loan spreads?
reference:
Mike Mayo (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

text: And on the topic of loan pricing, why aren't your credit card yields going higher than where they are today? Thanks.
reference:
Mike Mayo (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

text: Yeah, Mike. So I think, yeah, you're referring to my comments that I made in the Commercial Bank about the fact that the larger Corporate segment within the Commercial Bank that would generally have access to capital markets but also access to bank lending, at the margin is choosing to draw down revolvers right now rather than access the capital markets.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

text: That is not a particularly meaningful driver of the increase in NII guidance. There's a lot of odds and ends in there, but the major drivers are the ones that I called out.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

text: And to be honest, I haven't actually specifically checked what's happening with Card yields. I would imagine that they've gone up a little bit in line with rates, but I don't know. We should follow up here.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

text: All right. And then one for you, Jamie. I guess taking the 10,000 foot level, I guess, when you look at asset liability management, or ALM – you could call this nightmare on ALM street, and you've seen some big problems at banks, and I guess how would you evaluate yourself, I guess, with this $7 billion higher NII guide?
reference:
Mike Mayo (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

text: It probably is good, but to what degree are you willing to sacrifice JPM shareholder money to help rescue problem banks that did not get their asset liability management correctly?
reference:
Mike Mayo (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

text: Well, it's two really different questions. So we've been quite cautious on interest rates for quite a while, and how we invest our portfolio, what our expectations are, our stress testing.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: The stress test – the CCAR stress test, as you know, had rates going down. I always looked at rates going up and being prepared – whether or not anything is going to happen.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: So we've been quite conservative ourselves and we don't mind continuing to do that because I remind people that having excess capital, you haven't lost it.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: It's kind of earnings in store – you get to deploy it later and maybe at a more opportune time, when the time comes.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: And look, we like to help the system when it needs help, if we can reasonably. And we're not the only ones, you saw a lot of banks do that, and I was proud of them. I think all of us did the right thing.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: Whether ultimately it works out or not, well, you could second-guess that when it happens. But the fact is, I think people want to help the system.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: And this whole banking thing was bad for banks. And I knew that the second I saw the headline, and then you had Credit Suisse.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: We want healthy community banks. We want healthy regional banks. We want to help them get through this.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: We have, you'll remember, Mike, as you point out, we have the best financial system the world's ever seen.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: That does not mean it won't have problems, doesn't mean there shouldn't be changes made, but I think it's reasonable for people to help each other in times of need.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: And we all did that – all of us – did that during COVID. All of us did that – if you could, those who could – did it during the Great Financial Crisis, and I would expect people to do that going forward.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: Hey Jamie, your CEO letter said the banking crisis isn't over. So, what do you mean by that? Or was that dated two weeks later? Are you talking contagion or what?
reference:
Mike Mayo (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: Yeah. So it's just – the number of banks offsides you can count on your hands, in terms of too much interest rate exposure, too much ATM, too much uninsured deposits.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: And so there may be additional bank failures, something like that, which we don't know.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: But you're going to see next week regional banks have pretty good numbers. A lot of people are going to have – can take – actions to remediate some of the issues they may have going forward.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: You've already seen things calm down quite a bit, particularly in deposit flows.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: Warren Buffett was on TV talking about that he would bet $1 million – I don't know if you saw that – that no depositor will lose money in America. That he's willing to bet his own money.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: And of course, you know he's a very bright man.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: So, this crisis is not 2008. It will pass.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: And the one thing I pointed out is, when I answered the question just before about interest rates – people need to be prepared. They shouldn't pray that they don't go up. They should prepare for them going up. And if it doesn't happen, serendipity.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: All right. Thank you.
reference:
Mike Mayo (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: Yeah.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

Operator (Host)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: Hi. Good morning.

JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: Hey, Betsy.

Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 13

Betsy L. Graseck (Analyst)

JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 13

text: No, hear me? Hello?

text: Yeah. You're back now.

JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 13

reference:
Betsy L. Graseck (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 13

text: So, in the event that you get that higher for longer, just how much does that impact NII ex. Markets because I'm trying to triangulate here about – maybe you lose some deposits, but if we have higher for longer, shouldn't we expect the trajectory goes up from this quarter as opposed to down? Is that – that's the question.
reference:
Betsy L. Graseck (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 13

text: Go ahead, Jeremy. And then I'll go.

reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 13

text: You also obviously know that our current EaR actually shows a slight negative number, so a tiny bit liability sensitive, and I won't get into all the nuances about why that may or may not be a great predictor in the short-term.

Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 13

text: But the point is that the level of rates now is of course very different from what it was last year.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 13

text: And at this level of rates, the relationship between our short-term NII evolution and the curve is not always going to be clear in any given moment.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 13

text: It's quite tricky, and it can behave in somewhat wonky ways as a function of, again, what I've alluded to a couple times on this call – the competitive environment for deposits, which is not, in fact, a sort of mathematically predictable thing as a function of the rate curve. So, that's why we're emphasizing all the different drivers of uncertainty in the NII outlook. Yeah.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 13

text: Yeah. So I'll just add, so next quarter we all kind of know already. Two quarters out, we know a little bit less. Three quarters out, we know a little bit less. And 2024, we know very little.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 14

text: That number, you could imagine – this is a little inside baseball now – the number that we're talking about for 2024 is not based upon an implied curve. It's based upon us looking at multiple potential scenarios, leveling them kind of out and saying this is kind of a range.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 14

text: And you're absolutely correct. You could have an environment of higher for longer that might be better than that, but remember, higher for longer comes with a lot of other things attached to it – like maybe a recession, stagflation, lower volumes.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 14

reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 14

text: Yeah. Got it. Okay, that's super helpful to understand how you think through that. And then the follow-up is just on the buybacks. So do I take your comments to mean that you're on pause now?

JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 14

reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 14

text: And we're also peering ahead, looking at those little bit of storm clouds so we're going to be kind of cautious.
reference:

JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 14

reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 14

text: Yeah. And then can you give us any sense of what Basel IV endgame means to you in your RWAs? How much should we be baking in for those?

Betsy L. Graseck (Analyst)

JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 14

reference:

JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 14

text: I think now it feels like it’s likely to be worse than that. Hopefully, it’s not too much worse than that.

Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 14

reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 14

Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 14

text: Got it.
reference:

JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 14

reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 14

text: And JPMorgan – there's so much capital. I mean, so you can't look at JPMorgan and say, well, it's a capital issue.

JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 14

text: And even the banks, by the way, when you look at it – even though some of the banks that are in trouble, they have plenty of capital. Their issue wasn't capital, it was other things. And so I'm just hoping regulators are very thoughtful.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 14

Jamie Dimon (CEO)

reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 15

reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 15

text: What I would call more like operational cash –  so think even of a small companies, middle market companies, et cetera – that tends to be fairly sticky because you have your loans there, you have your money there, you're getting more and more competitive in rates.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 15

text: And that's why I think you see lot of regional banks – they've got sticky middle market deposits.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 15

reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 15

Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 15

reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 15

text: Operator: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to JPMorgan Chase's First Quarter 2024 Earnings Call. This call is being recorded. Your line will be muted for the duration of the call. We will now go live to the presentation. Please standby.
reference:
Operator (Host)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: At this time, I would like to turn the call over to JPMorgan Chase's Chairman and CEO, Jamie Dimon; and Chief Financial Officer, Jeremy Barnum. Mr. Barnum, please go ahead.
reference:
Operator (Host)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: Thank you very much, and good morning, everyone. The presentation is available on our website and please refer to the disclaimer in the back.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: Starting on page 1 – the firm reported net income of $13.4 billion, EPS of $4.44 on revenue of $42.5 billion and delivered an ROTCE of 21%.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: These results included a $725 million increase to the special assessment resulting from the FDIC's updated estimate of expected losses from the closures of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: Touching on a couple of highlights. Firmwide IB fees were up 18% year-on-year, reflecting particular strength in underwriting fees, and we've seen strong net inflows across AWM as well as in the CCB Wealth Management business.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: On page 2, we have some more detail. This is the last quarter we'll discuss results excluding First Republic given that, going forward, First Republic results will naturally be included in the prior period, making year-on-year results comparable. For this quarter, First Republic contributed $1.7 billion of revenue, $806 million of expense and $668 million of net income.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: Now, focusing on the Firmwide results excluding First Republic – revenue of $40.9 billion was up $1.5 billion or 4% year-on-year. NII ex. Markets was up $736 million or 4%, driven by the impact of balance sheet mix and higher rates as well as higher revolving balances in Card, largely offset by deposit margin compression and lower deposit balances in CCB.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: NIR ex. Markets was up $1.2 billion or 12%, driven by higher Firmwide Asset Management and Investment Banking fees as well as lower net investment securities losses.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: And Markets revenue was down $400 million or 5% year-on-year.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: Expenses of $22 billion were up $1.8 billion or 9% year-on-year, driven by higher compensation, including growth in employees and the increase to the FDIC's special assessment.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: And credit costs were $1.9 billion, reflecting net charge-offs of $2 billion and a net reserve release of $38 million. Net charge-offs were up $816 (sic) million, predominately driven by Card.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: On the balance sheet and capital, on page 3. We ended the quarter with a CET1 ratio of 15%, relatively flat versus the prior quarter, reflecting net income which was predominantly offset by higher RWA and capital distribution. text: So, a couple of questions here. Just, one, Jamie, could you talk through the decision to raise the dividend kind of mid-cycle, it felt like, pre-CCAR? And also, help us understand how you're thinking about where that payout ratio, that dividend payout ratio, range should be. text: Yeah. So, Betsy, before I answer the question, I want to say something on behalf of all of us at JPMorgan and, me personally, thrilled to have you on this call. For those that don't know, Betsy has been through a terrible medical episode and it's a reminder to all of us how lucky we are to be here. But, Betsy, in particular, the amount of respect we have, not just in your work, but in your character over the last 20 plus years has been exceptional. So, on behalf of all of us, I just want to welcome you back and thrilled to have you here.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: And so, you're asking a pertinent question. So, we're earning a lot of money. Our capital cup runneth over, and that's why we've increased the dividend. And if you're asking me what we'd like to do is to pay out something like a third, a third of normalized earnings. Of course, it's hard to calculate always what normalized earnings are, but we don't mind being a little bit ahead of that sometimes, a little bit behind that sometimes.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: If I could give people kind of consistent dividend guidance, et cetera, I think the far more important question is the 15%. So, look at the 15%, I'm going to oversimplify it, that basically will prepare us for the total Basel Endgame today, roughly. The specifics don't matter that much.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: Remember, we can do a lot of things to change that in the short-run or the long-run, but it looks like Basel III Endgame may not be the worst case. It'll be something less than that. So, obviously, when and if that happens, it would free up a lot of capital, and I'm going to say in the order of $20 billion or something like that.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 5

text: And, yes, we've always had the capital hierarchy the same way, which is we're going to use capital to build our business first, I mean, pay the dividend – steady dividend, build the business, and if we think it's appropriate to buy back stock. We're continuing to buy back stock at $2 billion a quarter (sic). I personally do not want to buy back a lot more than that at these current prices. I think you've all heard me talk about the world, things like that. So, waiting in preparation for Basel. Hopefully we'll know something later, and then we can be much more specific with you all.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 5

text: But in the meantime, there's also – it's very important to put in mind, there are short-term uses for capital that are good for shareholders, that could reduce our CET1 too. So, you may see us do things in the short-run that will increase earnings, increase capital, that are using up that capital. Jeremy mentioned on the – on one of the things that we know, the balance sheet and how we use the balance sheet for credit and trading, we could do things now.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 5

text: So, it's a great position to be in. We're going to be very, very patient. I urge all the analysts to keep in mind, excess capital is not wasted capital, it's earnings in store. We will deploy it in a very good way for shareholders in due course.

text: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from Jim Mitchell with Seaport Global. You may proceed.
reference:
Operator (Host)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 5

text: Hey. Good morning. Jeremy, can you speak to the trends you're seeing with respect to deposit migration in the quarter, if there's been any change? Have you seen that migration start to slow or not?
reference:
Jim Mitchell (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: Yeah. Good question, Jim. I think the simplest and best answer to that is: not really. So, as we've been saying for a while, migration from checking and savings to CDs is sort of the dominant trend with this driving the increase in weighted average rate paid in the consumer deposit franchise, that continues. We continue to capture that money-in-motion at a very high rate. We're very happy about what that means about the consumer franchise and level of engagement that we're seeing.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: I'm aware that there's a little bit of a narrative out there about are we seeing the end of what people sometimes refer to as cash sorting. We've looked at that data. We see some evidence that maybe it's slowing a little bit. We're quite cautious on that. We really sort of don't think it makes sense to assume that in a world where checking and savings is paying effectively zero and the policy rate is above 5% that you're not going to see ongoing migration.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: And frankly, we expect to see that even in a world where – even if the current yield curve environment were to change and meaningful cuts were to get reintroduced and we would actually start to see those, we would still expect to see ongoing migration and yield-seeking behavior. So, it's quite conceivable and this is actually on the yield curve that we had in fourth quarter that had six cuts in it. We were still nonetheless expecting an increase in weighted average rate paid as that migration continues. So, I would say no meaningful change in the trends and the expectation for ongoing migration is very much still there.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: Okay. And just a follow-up on that and just sort of bigger picture on NII. Is that sort of the biggest driver of your outlook? Is it migration? Is it the forward curve? Is it balances? It sounds like it's migration, but just I'd be curious to hear your thoughts on the biggest drivers of upside or downside.
reference:
Jim Mitchell (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: Yeah. So, I mean I think the drivers of, let's say, what's embedded in the current guidance is actually not meaningfully different from what it was in the fourth quarter, meaning it's the current yield curve, which is a little bit stale now. But the snap from quarter-end had roughly three cuts in it. So, it's the current yield curve, it's what I just said, the expectation of ongoing internal migration. There is some meaningful offset from Card revolve growth, which while it's a little bit less than it was in prior years, is still a tailwind there.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: We expect deposit balances to be sort of flat to modestly down, so that's a little bit of a headwind at the margin. And then, there's obviously the wild card of potential product level reprice, which we always say we're going to make those decisions situationally as a function of competitive conditions in the marketplace, and you know this obviously, but in a world where we've got something like $900 billion of deposits paying effectively zero, relatively small changes in the product level reprice can change the NII run rate by a lot. So, the error bands here are pretty wide, and we're always going to stick with our mantra, which has been not losing primary bank relationships and thinking about the long-term health of the franchise when we think about deposit pricing.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: Right. Okay. Great. Thanks for the color.

Jim Mitchell (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: Thanks.

JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

We didn't see that this quarter. Is that just kind of seasonal? And would you still expect the kind of growth math to play out in terms of Card growth and reserve build needs?
reference:
John McDonald (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: Yeah, John. So, in short, yes to both questions. So, yes, the relative lack of build this quarter is a function of the normal seasonal patterns of Card. Yes, we still expect 12% Card loan growth for the full year. And yes, that still means that all else equal, we think the consensus for the allowance build for the back three quarters is still a little too low, if you map it to that expected Card loan growth.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: Obviously, there's the wild card of what happens with our probabilities and our parameters and the output of our internal process of assessing the skew in the seasonal distribution and so on, and we're not speaking to that one way or the other. So, if guys have your own opinions about that, that's fine, but we're narrowly just saying that based on the Card loan growth that we expect and normal coverage ratios for that, we do expect build in the back half of the year.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: Okay. Got it. And then just to follow up to make it super clear on the idea of the Markets NII, that outlook being revised down by $1 billion but revenue neutral. I guess, the obvious thing is, there, there's typically an offset in fee income and you don't guide to that. But the idea would be the way you're structuring trades, the way the balance sheet is evolving, there’s some offset that you'd expect in Markets fees from the lower Markets NII, correct?
reference:
John McDonald (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: That is exactly right. And specifically, what's going on here is there's shift between on-balance sheet and off-balance sheet in the financing businesses and prime and so on within Markets. And you can actually see a little bit of a pop in the Markets balance sheet in the supplement and these things are all related.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: So, fundamentally, you can think of it as like we either hold the equities on the balance sheet, non-interest-bearing, high-funding expense, negative for NII, or we receive that in total return form through derivatives, exactly the same economics, no impact on NII. So, that shift is a function of the sort of borrowing relationships in the marketplace in ways that are bottom line effectively neutral. It's second order effects, but they change the geography quite a bit, and that's what happened this quarter. And that's why we've been emphasizing for some time that the NII ex. Markets is the better number to focus on in terms of an indicator of how the core banking franchise is performing.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: Got it. Thank you.

JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: Thank you.

text: Hey. Good morning. And when we think about higher-for-longer, maybe the economy is too strong so we don't get any rate cuts, are you seeing that when you talk to your customers and the feedback you're getting from your bankers where the momentum is picking up?
reference:
Ebrahim H. Poonawala (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: And I appreciate all the macro risks that Jamie has pointed out, but I'm just getting – trying to get to a sense of what your view is in terms of the most likely outcome based on what you're seeing today from the customers.
reference:
Ebrahim H. Poonawala (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: I would say consumer customers are fine. The unemployment is very low. Home prices are up. Stock prices are up. The amount of income they need to service their debt is still kind of low, but the extra money of the lower-income folks is running out – not running out, but normalizing, and you see credit normalizing a little bit. And of course, higher-income folks still have more money, they're still spending it. So, whatever happens, the customer is in pretty good shape and they're – if they – you go into a recession, they'll be in pretty good shape.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: Businesses are in good shape. If you look at it today, their confidence is up, their order books are up, their profits are up. But what I caution people, these are all the same results of a lot of fiscal spending, a lot of QE, et cetera. And so, we don't really know what's going to happen. And I also want to look at the year. Look at two years or three years, all the geopolitical effects and oil and gas and how much fiscal spending will actually take place, our elections, et cetera.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: So, we're in good shape – we're okay right now. It does not mean we're okay down the road. And if you look at any inflection point, being okay in the current time is always true. That was true in 1972. It was true in any time we've had it. So, I just – I'm just on the more cautious side. How people feel and confidence levels and all that, that doesn't necessarily stop you from having an inflection point. And so, everything is okay today, but you've got to be prepared for a range of outcomes, which we are.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: And the other thing I want to point out, because all of these questions about interest rates and yield curves and NII and credit losses, it's – one thing to project it today based on what – not what we think in economic scenarios, but the generally accepted economic scenario, which is the generally accepted rate cuts of the Fed, but these numbers have always been wrong.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: You have to ask the question, what if other things happen like higher rates with this modest recession, et cetera? Then all these numbers change. I just don't think any of us should be surprised if and when that happens. And I just think the chance of happening is higher than other people. I don't know the outcome. We don't want to guess the outcome. I've never seen anyone actually positively predict big inflection point in the economy, literally in my life or in history.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: That's helpful. And just tied to that, as we look at commercial real estate both for J.P. and for the economy overall, is higher rates alone enough to create more vulnerability than issues beyond office CRE? Like, how would you characterize the health of the CRE market? Thank you.
reference:
Ebrahim H. Poonawala (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: Yeah, so I'll put it into two buckets. Okay? First of all, we're fine. We've got good reserves against office. We think our multifamily is fine. Jeremy can give you more detail on that if you want.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: But if you think of real estate, there's two pieces. If rates go up, think of the yield curve. The whole yield curve, not Fed funds, but the 10-year bond rate, it goes up 2%, all assets, all assets, every asset on the planet, including real estate, is worth 20% less. Well, obviously, that creates a little bit of stress and strain, and people have to roll those over and finance it more. That's not just true for real estate, it's true for everybody. And that happens, leveraged loans, real estate will have some effect.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: The second thing is the, why does that happen? If that happens because we have a strong economy, well, that's not so bad for real estate because people will be hiring and throwing things out and other financial assets. If that happens because we have stagflation, well that’s the worst case.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: All of a sudden, you are going to have more vacancies, you are going to have more companies cutting back, you are going to have less leases. It will affect – including multifamily, that will filter through the whole economy in a way that we – people haven't really experienced since 2010.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: So, I just put in the back of your mind the why is important, the interest rates are important, the recession is important. If things stay where they are today, we have kind of the soft landing that seems to be embedded in the marketplace, everyone will – the real estate will muddle through. Obviously, it will be idiosyncratic if you're in different cities and different types and B versus A buildings and all of that, but people muddle through. They won't muddle through under higher rates with the recession. That would be tough for a lot of folks and not just real estate if, in fact, that happens.
reference:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: Helpful. Thank you so much.
reference:
Ebrahim H. Poonawala (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: Thanks, Ebrahim.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: Hi. Good morning. Given that your response to Betsy's question is that 15% CET1 today prepares you for Basel III Endgame as written, you earn 22% on – without the FDIC assessment. Ahead of Investor Day, I guess, six weeks from now or a week from now, as we think about that 17% through-the-cycle target, if you're at the right capital level per you guys, where are you over-earning today?
reference:
Erika Najarian (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: Right. So, interesting framing of the question, Erika. So, I think we've been pretty consistent about where we're over-earning, right? So, obviously, one major area is that we're over-earning in deposit margin, especially in consumer and that's sort of why we're expecting sequential declines in NII, why we've talked about compressing deposit margins and increases in weighted average rate paid. So, I think that's probably the single biggest source of, let's call it, excess earnings currently.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: You also have heard Jamie say that we're over-earning in credit. I mean, Wholesale charge-offs have been particularly low, but we have builds for that. So, in the current run rate, a bit less clear the extent of what we're earning. And in Card, of course, while charge-offs are now close to normalized essentially, we did go through an extended period of charge-offs being very low by historical standards, although that was coupled with NII also being low by historical standards. So, from a bottom line perspective, it's not entirely clear what the net of that was. But broadly, it's really deposit margin that's the biggest single factor in the over-earning narrative.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: Embedded in your question, I think, is a little bit of the “what are you thinking about the 17% CET1 in light of the current level of capital” and so on and you did talk about Investor Day. reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: At the rate we're going, we won't actually know that much more about that by Investor Day, so we might not have that much more to say except to reiterate what I've said in the past which is that, whatever it is, it's going to be very good, our returns in absolute terms, very good in relative terms. We will optimize, we will seek to reprice, we will adjust in various ways to the best of our ability. But given the structure of the rule as proposed at least, a lot of this cannot be optimized away. And so, in the base case you have to think of it as a headwind.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: Got it. And just as a follow-up question, you mentioned that the current curve that you set your NII outlook upon is stale. I guess, does it matter that – it seems like the market down pricing, and obviously no June cut, no September cut and a toss-up in December, which should matter for this year. As we think about that $90 billion, if we price rate cuts out totally, does that matter much given it seems like June is the only one that would...
reference:
Erika Najarian (Analyst)

text: Yeah. Sorry, Erika. So, just quick things on this. One, let's focus on NII ex., not on total NII. So, I'd anchor you to the $89 billion. reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 10

text: But I would just once again remind you of the $900 billion of deposits paying practically zero, that very small changes there can make a big difference. And we've got other factors. We're giving you our best guess based on a series of assumptions and it's going to be where it's going to be.

Jeremy Barnum (CFO)

reference:
Ken Usdin (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 10

text: Sure. Yeah. Let me take the IPO first. So, we have been a little bit cautious there. Some cohorts and vintages of IPOs had performed somewhat disappointingly. I think that narrative has changed to a meaningful degree this quarter. So I think we're seeing better IPO performance. Obviously, Equity Markets have been under a little bit of pressure last few days. But in general, we have a lot of support there and that always helps.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 10

text: Dialogue is quite good. A lot of interesting different types of conversations happening with global firms, multinationals, carve-out type things. So, dialogue is good. Valuation environment is better, like sort of decent reasons for optimism there. But of course, with ECM, there's always a pipeline dynamic and conditions were particularly good this quarter. And so, we cautioned a little bit there about pull-forward. Which is even more acute I think on the DCM side, given that quite a higher percentage of the total amount of debt that needed to be refinanced this year, has gotten done in the first quarter. So, that's a factor.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 10

text: And then, the question of M&A I think is probably the single most important question, not only because of its impact on M&A, but also because of it's knock-on impact on DCM through acquisition, financing and so on. I don't know, I've heard some narratives that maybe there is like some pent-up deal demand. Who knows how important politics are in all this? So, I don't know.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

text: We're fundamentally, as I said, I think on the press call, happy to see momentum this quarter. Happy to see momentum in announced M&A. A little bit cautious about the pull-forward dynamic. A little bit cautious about the regulatory headwinds. And in the end, we're just going to fight really hard for our share of the wallet here.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

text: Got it. And I guess, I'll just stick on the theme of capital markets, and not surprising at all to see a little bit tougher comp in FICC. I think you guys have kind of indicated that maybe a flattish fee pool is a reasonable place, and I know that's impossible to guide on. But just, maybe talk to some of the dynamics in terms of activity across the Fixed Income and Equities business. And do you feel like this is the type of environment where, given that lingering uncertainty about rates, clients are either more engaged or less engaged in terms of how they're positioning portfolios? Thanks.
reference:
Ken Usdin (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

text: Yeah. Really good question. I would say, in general, that the sort of volatility and uncertainty in the rate environment overall on balance is actually supportive for the Markets revenue pool. And I think that, together with generally more balance sheet deployment as well as sort of some level of natural background growth, is one of the reasons that the overall level of Markets revenue has stabilized at meaningfully above what was normal in the pre-pandemic period.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

text: And well, that does occasionally make us a little bit anxious like, “Oh, is this sustainable? Might there be downside here?” For now, that does seem to be the new normal. And I do think that having rates off the lower zero bound and a sort of more normal dynamic and global rates, that not only affects the rates business, but it affects the Foreign Exchange business. It generally just makes asset allocation decisions more important and more interesting.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

text: And so, all of that creates risk management needs and active managers need to grapple with it, and so on and so forth. So, I think that – those are some of the themes on the Market side at the margin. And yeah, we'll see how the rest of the year goes. But it sort of seems to be behaving relatively normally, I would say.

JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

On the other hand, the firm is investing so much more outside the U.S., whether it's commercial or some digital banking, consumer or wholesale payments. So, I'm just trying to reconcile kind of your actions with your words.
reference:
Mike Mayo (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

reference:
Mike Mayo (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

text: Right, Mike. So I’m sorry to tell you that Jamie actually left us because he’s at a leadership off-site. That’s why he was here remote. So, I think he left the call in my hands, for better or for worse. But let me try to address some of your points and without sort of speaking for Jamie here.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

text: I think that when we talk about the impact of the geopolitical uncertainty on the outlook, part of the point there is to note that the U.S. is not isolated from that. If we have global macroeconomic problems as a result of geopolitical situations, that’s not only a problem outside of the U.S.; that affects the global economy and therefore the US and therefore our corporate customers, et cetera, et cetera.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: And in that context, keeping in mind what we always say that we invest through-the-cycle, that we sort of, we don’t go into countries and then leave countries, et cetera. Obviously, we adjust around the edges, we manage risks, we do make choices as a function of the overall geopolitical environment. But broadly, the notion that we would pull back meaningfully from one of the key competitive strengths that this company has always had which is, its sort of global character because of a particular moment geopolitically, would just be inconsistent with how we've always operated.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: And in terms of the Wholesale Payments business, it's going great. We're taking share. There's been a lot of innovation there, a lot of investment in technology, a lot of connectivity to payment systems in different countries around the world. And yeah, I'm sure we'll give you more color in other settings on that, but it's a good story. It's a nice thing to see.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: Just as a follow up to that then, why is it doing great in terms of Wholesale Payments, given such the – the dislocations in the world from wars to supply chain changes, everything else? Why is Wholesale Payments doing great?
reference:
Mike Mayo (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: Well, I think one of the things about Payments businesses is that, in some sense they are – I mean, recession proof is probably the wrong word; and in any case, we're not dealing with the recession. We're talking fundamentally about moving money through pipes around the world, and that's a thing that people need to do more or less, no matter what. So, that's one piece.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: But I think the other piece is that, our willingness to invest which has always been a focus of yours, is one of the key things separating us in this business right now. And so, we are seeing the benefits of that.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: Alright. Thank you.

JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: Thanks, Mike.

Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: Thank you. Your commentary with Ken's questions were great and clear on Investment Banking for the near term in this year. reference:
Glenn Schorr (Analyst)

So, it's like four years ago at this point. So, there has been GDP growth, especially in nominal terms during that period, and you would expect the wallet to growth with that.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 13

text: So, I do think there's meaningful upside in the Investment Banking fee wallet. As I've noted, there are some headwinds, I think particularly in M&A. And, yeah, so that's why we're sort of leaning in. We're engaging with clients. We're making sure that we're appropriately resourced for a more robust level of the wallet and fighting for every dollar of share.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 13

text: Cool. Maybe one other follow-up. You're always investing. You clearly get paid in growth across the franchise as you do. Morgan pull back on this tremendous investment spending wave that you've been going through?
reference:
Glenn Schorr (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 13

text: Sure. So, I think the first thing to say which is somewhat obvious but I'm going to say it anyway is that, there are some like auto-governors in this, right? Like some portion of the expense base is directly related to revenue, whether it's volume-related commissions, whether it's incentive compensation, whether it's other things. So, there are some auto-correcting elements of the expense base that would happen automatically as part of the normal discipline. So, that's point one.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 13

text: Point two is that, independently of the environment, we are always looking for efficiencies. But that is part of the DNA of the company, that does happen in BAU all the time as we grind things out, get the benefits of scale and try to extract that efficiency.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 13

text: And I think to get to the heart of your question which is, okay, in what type of an environment would we make different strategic questions? And in the end, I think that's a little bit about what that environment is really like. No, we wouldn't.
reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 13

reference:

JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 13

text: Good morning. You mentioned one use of capital is to lean into the trading businesses with your balance sheet. reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 14

reference:

reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)

text: Got it. And then just separately, within the Consumer Card businesses, you highlighted volumes were up 9% year-over-year. Obviously, still a very strong piece. reference:

reference:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
