reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 17

text: The company's overall investment banking fees were 1.2 billion in the second quarter, growing 7% over the prior year and 4% linked quarter, a good performance in a sluggish environment that saw fee pools down 20% year over year.
reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 17

text: Provision expense declined year over year as we built more reserve in the prior year.
reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 17

text: Expense was held relatively flat year over year even as we drove strategic investments in the business, including relationship management hiring and technology costs.
reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 17

text: And additionally, comparisons benefit from the absence of elevated expense for some regulatory matters in the second quarter of '22.
reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 17

text: Switching to global markets on Slide 22. Team had another strong quarter with earnings growing to 1.2 billion driven by revenue growth of 14%.
reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 18

text: And I'm referring to results excluding DVA as we normally do.
reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 18

text: The continued themes of inflation, geopolitical tensions, and central banks changing monetary policies around the globe, along with this quarter's debt ceiling concerns, continue to impact both the bond and equity markets.
reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 18

text: And as a result, it was a quarter where we saw strong performance in both our macro and micro trading businesses.
reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 18

text: The investments made in the business over the past two years continue to produce favorable results.
reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 18

text: Year-over-year revenue growth benefited from strong sales and trading results and the absence of marks on leveraged finance positions last year.
reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 18

text: Focusing on sales and trading. Ex DVA revenue improved 10% year over year to 4.4 billion.
reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 18

text: FICC improved 18%, while equities was down 2% compared to the second quarter of '22.
reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 18

text: Year-over-year expense increased 8%, primarily driven by investments in the business and revenue-related costs, partially offset by the absence of regulatory matters in the second quarter of '22.
reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 18

text: Finally on Slide 23, all other shows a loss of 182 million.
reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 18

text: Revenue included 197 million of losses on security sales and increased volume of solar and wind investment operating losses that create the tax credits for the company.
reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 18

text: As a result of the increased solar and wind tax deal volume and their associated related operating losses, our effective tax rate in the quarter was lower 8%.
reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 18

text: But excluding ESG and any other discrete tax benefits, our tax rate would have been 26%.
reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 18

text: So with that, let's stop there, and we'll open it up for Q&A.
reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 18

text: [Operator instructions] We'll take our first question today from Gerard Cassidy with RBC. Your line is open.
reference:
Operator (Host)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 19

text: Thank you. Good morning, Brian. Good morning, Alastair.
reference:
Gerard Cassidy (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 19

text: Brian, can you give us a view from your standpoint of the -- the new proposal -- or when I say new but the speech by Vice Chair Barr about the likelihood of capital ratios going up for large banks like your own?
reference:
Gerard Cassidy (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 19

text: And then second, there was a report today on Bloomberg that the capital requirements for holding residential mortgages may go up meaningfully. Any thoughts on that as well?
reference:
Gerard Cassidy (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 19

text: I think, broadly stated, I think, as was said by many people that have held the position over the years, the capital industry is sufficient.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 19

text: And I think there's been a desire to finish up the Basel III. Those rules will come out, we think, in a few weeks.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 19

text: And, you know, like anything else, we'll deal with them. We have 11.6% CET 1 ratio. Our requirements currently are 10.4.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 19

text: And so, we've got plenty of capital and it's built up.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 19

text: So, you know, I think, from the global competitive standpoint, we've got to be careful here because the U.S. industry is the best industry in the -- in the world and actually does a lot of good for all the countries including the U.S.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 19

text: And -- and frankly, the rules applied tend to be more favorable to those outside our country. And so, we ought to be careful to maintain that competitive parity.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 19

text: But at the end of the day, Gerard, you know, you need to finish this and get this behind us and then the industry will adopt and move forward.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 20

text: And -- but they've got to think through the downside of some of these rules and that they can push stuff outside the industry to nonbanks to half the asset classes across the board.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 20

text: And nonbanks, including mortgage lending, which you referenced, half of it goes through nonbanks.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 20

text: And those -- the resilience of those institutions is interesting to watch through cycles.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 20

text: And then, the second thing they have to worry about is competitiveness overall.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 20

text: But and then, also just slowing down the economy, a 10% increase in our capital levels would disable us from making about $150 billion of loans at the margin. And you want our banks to support the economy like we do.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 20

text: So, I think all of this has to be balanced out as they go to adopt these rules.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 20

text: Very good. And then, as a follow-up, Alastair, you talked about the balance sheet.
reference:
Gerard Cassidy (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 20

text: I think you said 100-basis-point increase would lead to over $3 billion in net interest revenue growth over the next 12 months, and 100-basis-point decrease would lead to a decline of just over $3 billion in Revenue.
reference:
Gerard Cassidy (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 20

text: Can you share with us, when do you think you might change -- or what would make you change that position to be liability sensitive?
reference:
Gerard Cassidy (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 20

text: Would you rely on the forward curve? Or what's the outlook for the balance sheet management that you're looking at now?
reference:
Gerard Cassidy (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 20

text: Well, Gerard, I don't think much has changed for us. We've talked about the fact that, you know, for us, it's this idea of balance that's key.
reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 20

text: And if you look at our disclosures around interest rate risk over the course of the past couple of years, you'll see it's -- it's more balanced, both upside and downside.
reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 20

text: And it's a narrower corridor over time. So, we're trying to sustain NII at a higher level for longer. That's what we're trying to engineer.
reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 21

text: So, I think, going forward, there won't be a lot of change to our philosophy in that regard. We feel like we're in a pretty good position in terms of balance.
reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 21

text: We'll be tweaking at the margin, but what will largely drive things from here is just normalization of deposits and -- and good old-fashioned loan growth.
reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 21

text: Very good. Thank you.
reference:
Gerard Cassidy (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 21

text: We'll go next to Glenn Schorr with Evercore. Your line is open.
reference:
Operator (Host)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 21

text: Hey, Glenn.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 21

text: Good morning. So, no one could take issue with 600 basis points of operating leverage, but I just always like doing a little gut check.
reference:
Glenn Schorr (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 21

text: Expenses, up 5%. I heard all the reasons why a lot of investment, the FDIC charges coming, but I just want to make sure, did anything change?
reference:
Glenn Schorr (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 21

text: Over the, like, last decade or so, you've been basically flat for life. Is expenses more of a relative gain relative to revenues?
reference:
Glenn Schorr (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 21

text: Or do you think you can keep expenses in and around the same area as you continue to invest? Thanks.
reference:
Glenn Schorr (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 21

text: I -- so, Glenn, I think Alastair gave you a trajectory, which if you look at it from fourth quarter last year to the fourth quarter this year, gets relatively flat year over year.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 22

text: And as revenues flatten out because the interest rate movements flatten out, you know, you'll see that, as we decline in the quarters, that'll be strong.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 22

text: So, if we think about it, the -- as we think about the forward, you know, we think about the -- the ability to control headcount and have expenses continue to come down.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 22

text: But they're going to stay, you know, at a level that's relatively consistent where we are now over time. And the goal is then to grow revenue faster than expense.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 22

text: We've been doing it for many decades. You can see that in our data.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 22

text: And -- and -- but the way we do it differs, you know, from five years ago to 10 years ago to last year.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 22

text: And that the ability to, you know, move the branch configuration around when we had 6,000 branches down to 4,000 or 3,900, 3,800 is different from 3,800 to where it might end up.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 22

text: And so, you should expect us to continue to engineer by applying massive amounts of technology.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 22

text: Erica saves a lot of transactional activity. Zelle saves a lot of transactional activity deposits by mobile phone, saves a lot of activity, all that goes on.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 22

text: And then, what we're offsetting with that is from the decade that you talk about, we probably went from 2.5 billion of technology initiatives a year to 3.8 billion.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 22

text: And we went -- we have a lot more revenue that's compensated for, thinking about in the wealth management business.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 22

text: And that's -- those are things we fight all the time. So, we expect to manage expenses in line with the revenue.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 22

text: As we got to '19, we told you that we're going to have to start growing expenses at a modestly -- modest growth rate relative to the revenue growth rate.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 22

text: We'd outgrow the economy on revenue, and expenses will grow a couple hundred basis points lower.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 22

text: We're kind of going to be back in that mode, frankly. It's just, with inflation, they kicked up, and now, we flatten it back out and then we'll get back in sync as we move to '24 and beyond.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 22

text: And, Glenn, look, the only thing I would just add to what Brian just said, you know, we put up 16.2 in the first quarter. We were 16-ish this quarter.
reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 23

text: Obviously, yeah, we kind of feel like, next quarter, just with all the work that we've done around headcount and getting the firm in the place that we want now, we feel like we're well positioned to deliver 15.8 this quarter.
reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 23

text: If we -- when we keep going, we think we're going to be somewhere around 15.6 or so in Q4.
reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 23

text: So, to Brian's point, number one, we like the trajectory now. We've shaped the headcount over time to get to the place where we want it to be, and that would compare -- I think Q4 of last year was 15.5.
reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 23

text: So, when you talk about that sort of flattish idea, in an inflationary environment, we feel like that's a pretty good way to end this year and a pretty good way to set up for next year.
reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 23

text: Totally agree. Thanks for all that. I appreciate it.
reference:
Glenn Schorr (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 23

text: We'll take our next question from Mike Mayo with Wells Fargo. Your line is open.
reference:
Operator (Host)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 23

text: Good morning, Mike.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 23

text: Hey, good morning. So, I don't think consensus has you with positive outcome of the third and fourth quarter.
reference:
Mike Mayo (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 23

text: And I just want to make sure I heard you correctly, Brian, on your opening remark. You expect that eight quarters of consecutive positive operating leverage to continue.
reference:
Mike Mayo (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 23

text: So, you expect nine quarters or 10 quarters or as long as you can, and on the -- one reason is just the NII headwinds.
reference:
Mike Mayo (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 23

text: You said it should be kind of flattish in the third quarter, which -- and then down some in the fourth quarter.
reference:
Mike Mayo (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 24

text: You said the commercial loan demand is a little bit less and utilization is less.
reference:
Mike Mayo (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 24

text: On the other hand, you did this give some specific expense numbers. And maybe, I guess the specific question is, how long do you expect those eight quarters last?
reference:
Mike Mayo (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 24

text: Are we done with that? Do you expect that to go?
reference:
Mike Mayo (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 24

text: And then, to what degree do your digital efforts, you know, your first three slides, 4, 5, and 6, play a part in sustaining this positive operating leverage, say, through 2024 and 2025?
reference:
Mike Mayo (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 24

text: Is that a goal? Is that an expectation?
reference:
Mike Mayo (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 24

text: I -- our goal is always to maintain it. And like you point out, that the toughest time was when you have sort of a twist in the interest rate environment, and you could see that at the end of '19.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 24

text: And then, we got right back into it right after the environment stabilized.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 24

text: But, you know, I think about the question you asked me a few years ago, Mike, was, you know, when NII is coming in, are you going to let it fall the bottom line, are you going to spend it?
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 24

text: And about 80-plus percent of it has fallen to the bottom line, which shows you how we position the franchise from, you know, the second quarter of '21 till now as we went through the interest rate -- the fast interest rate raising.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 24

text: So, we gave you the specific -- as you said, the specific expense guidance by quarter.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 24

text: We'd expect that should produce operating leverage. We'll be hit -- it gets tougher and then it will get easier as we start to see the stabilization of deposits and loans and loan growth, you know, sort of routinely come through and the economy, frankly, shaking through whether we're going to have a recession or not.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 24

text: And so, we feel good about what we've done. That's why I tried to give that longer period of time, so people have the context.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 24

text: It's very different environments how we've achieved it. Sometimes, revenue fell and expense fell faster.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 24

text: Sometimes, revenue grew and expense grew but slower and, you know, all the different ways.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 24

text: So, we'll keep working at it. The key leading indicator we like is we've been able to manage the headcount down, as Alastair said earlier.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 25

text: And frankly, that is in the face of a turnover rate year over year which has dropped in half, which is good because then we're not training and hiring as many people.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 25

text: And that then sets us up for the second half of the year because that headcount benefit has not really come through the P&L, and we'll offset some of the other inflation.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 25

text: And then, as relates to NII specifically, you said that the last few months, you're a little bit more confident given stabilization in pricing.
reference:
Mike Mayo (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 25

text: I guess we're not seeing that every bank, right? Some bank getting worse, some banks getting better.
reference:
Mike Mayo (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 25

text: So, what is it that gives you more confidence on the NII front and the deposit stabilization front?
reference:
Mike Mayo (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 25

text: Well, I can't -- look, I can't speak to the other banks, Mike, but obviously, we know we're in a privileged and advantaged position relative to our client base.
reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 25

text: I just think it's interesting, you look at that global banking set of results over the course of the past year and a half in particular, that's extraordinary resilience.
reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 25

text: And, look, Q2 is tax season. So, you look at the wealth management business, for example, deposits were down 9 billion, but we know they paid tax payments of, you know, 14 billion, 15 billion, 16 billion last quarter.
reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 25

text: So, there's beginning to be a little more stability. And obviously, our focus has always been on transactional primary operating, and we're maybe seeing the benefit of that in some degree.
reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 25

text: But we'll -- we show you on slide -- I think it was Page 12 of the earnings deck, that's where it is. And we showed that last quarter.
reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 25

text: We show it again next quarter. But it's just, you know, the Fed's engineering this across the board, and we're just reacting to what we see from our customer base.
reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 25

text: OK. Thank you.
reference:
Mike Mayo (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 26

text: We'll take our next question from Jim Mitchell with Seaport Global. Your line is open.
reference:
Operator (Host)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 26

text: Hey, good morning. Maybe just a follow-up on -- on deposit behavior.
reference:
Jim Mitchell (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 26

text: I appreciate the comment that you have very low loan-to-deposit ratio, you know, off to chase rates.
reference:
Jim Mitchell (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 26

text: So, it feels like betas can stay low. But how do you think about -- how are you thinking about the mix going forward?
reference:
Jim Mitchell (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 26

text: We are seeing NIDs come down, CD demand is picking up. So, how are you thinking -- what are you seeing in your deposit base with respect to mix?
reference:
Jim Mitchell (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 26

text: I think, Jim, one of the things that, as we think about deposits, we think about across each of the customer bases and that's what Page 12 shows you.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 26

text: We think about what do they have cash flows for. They have cash to transact, and they have cash that's in excess of that.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 26

text: And what happens is, depending on the customer segment, that cash moves to the market, that excess cash moves the market. But the transactional cash is all with us.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 26

text: That transactional cash far exceeds for us our -- our loan balances. So, we have excess transactional cash.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 26

text: And a lot of it is low-interest checking, no-interest checking. Even if it's a money market, it's that sort of cushion that consumers and wealthy people -- wealthy consumers and average consumers maintain to pay their bills and unexpected expenses.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 26

text: So, that's what you've seen, and that produces a cost of deposits of 1.24, which is far different than we see other people have.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 27

text: And that -- that you can't -- that's just happened. So, now, the question is how much moves.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 27

text: And as Alastair said earlier, we're after tax time now where we have a big wealth management payout to the -- to the -- to taxes.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 27

text: We also are past the point where people have -- way past the point in the last stimulus payments where people have to -- that money's been in accounts, and still is in their accounts, to a large degree as we -- as we look at them.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 27

text: And they're paying that down slowly, so the average balance in our checking accounts has gone from a high of 11,000 at the peak to 10,000, you know, now to 600 or 500, something like that.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 27

text: So, all that dynamic. But you've got to go back and say it's the mix of interest bearing and noninterest bearing is actually a little bit of a misnomer because it's really what the customer uses it to cash for.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 27

text: And if they use it to transact and run their household, that's a very stable base. And that's what this data shows across time and is fundamentally a lot higher than pre-pandemic.
reference:

text: Thank you, Lee, and good morning, and thank all of you for joining us today. Before I begin today, I just want to reflect a second on the horrible events this weekend. text: With that, let's our attention to the results for the second quarter of 2024 Bank of America Corporation. This quarter, we achieved success in a number of areas, underscoring the benefits of our diversity and the dedication of our team to deliver responsible growth. Our organic growth engine continues to add customers and activity to all our businesses even as we see the drop in net interest income this quarter.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: I'm starting on Slide 2. Our net income for the quarter was $6.9 billion after tax or $0.83 in diluted EPS. Attesting to the balance in our franchise, the earnings were split evenly: half in our Consumer and GWIM businesses, which serve people, and the other half in our institutional-focused business, Global Banking and Markets.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: We grew revenue from the second quarter 2023, as improvement in noninterest income overcame the decline in net interest income. Fees grew 6% year-over-year and represented 46% of total revenue in the quarter.

Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Our strong fee performance was led by a 14% improvement in asset management fees in our wealth management businesses.

Bank of America, Q2, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: We grew investment banking fees 29% year-over-year and saw sales and trading revenue increase 7%.

Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Global Markets had its ninth consecutive quarter of year-over-year growth in sales and trading revenue – a good job by Jimmy DeMare and the team.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Card and service charge revenue also grew by 6% year-over-year in our Consumer business.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Much of this fee growth is a result of our intensity around organic growth and is a testament to the diversity of our operating model.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Now onto Slide 3. Organic growth has been driven by several key factors. First, we focus on our customers. We continue to place them at the center of everything we do.

Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Consumer led the way in delivering solid organic growth with high-quality accounts and engaged clients. For the 22nd consecutive quarter, we had significant net new consumer checking accounts. reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: In Wealth Management, we added another 6,100 new relationships this quarter. In our commercial businesses, we added thousands of small businesses and hundreds of commercial banking relationships.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: This has led to now managing $5.7 trillion in client balances, loans, deposits, and investments across the Consumer and Wealth Management client segments. In those areas, we saw flows of $58 billion in the past 4 quarters.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Our emphasis on personalized financial solutions and superior customer service has strengthened customer loyalty, attracting new clients across all our businesses. Our focus on providing liquidity and risk management solutions to our institutional clients positions us to continue to gain more share of the wallets as well.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Second, we continue to deliver innovative digital solutions. One of the primary contributors of both attracting and retaining customers to our platforms is our digital banking capabilities for our clients across all the businesses.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

Bank of America, Q2, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Fourth, organic growth is driving integrated flows across our business. We invest heavily in each line of business that compete in the markets based on their particular customer segment. text: It's a differentiated advantage for us: our banking leadership position across our businesses and our nationwide franchise. reference:

text: Next, we drive efficiency and effectiveness, and that's through our operational excellence platform. We continue to invest heavily in the future of our franchise and growth while we also have to manage expenses day-to-day.
reference:

Bank of America, Q2, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: Our focus on operational excellence has enabled us to hold our expense growth up to 2% year-over-year, well below the inflation rates. We continue to work to achieve operating leverage as NII stabilizes and begins to grow again.

Bank of America, Q2, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: As you look at it, and Alastair will explain later, a fair portion of the year-over-year increase in expense is due to the formulaic incentives of Wealth Management due to the fee growth in that business.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: And last, our capital strength allows us to deliver for all stakeholders. Our capital remained strong as we held our CET1 ratio at 11.9% this quarter.

Bank of America, Q2, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: We grew loans, increased our share repurchases to $3.5 billion and paid $1.9 billion in dividends. Average diluted shares dropped below 8 billion shares outstanding.

Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: In addition, we also announced our intent to increase our quarterly dividend 8% upon Board approval.

Bank of America, Q2, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: Let's turn to Slide 4. A couple of things to note here. First, we've noted for several quarters that the second quarter NII would be the trough for this rate cycle. text: The second quarter in reality is typically a heavy outflow quarter. We have a lot of customers who pay a lot of taxes in that quarter. text: The next couple categories are a result of natural management of interest rate risk in a balance sheet mixed with fixed-rate assets and variable-rate assets. And our balance sheet is split roughly half and half.
reference:

text: So we take in liquidity from customers that we used to fund our assets, and then we store excess liquidity in cash and securities. We have fixed assets that mature and pay down, and those supply cash that then gets put back to work on the balance sheet and reprices over time.

Alastair Borthwick (CFO)

text: And we have two basic categories of fixed assets that mature and pay off, and those are securities and loans. reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q2, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: On loans between resi mortgage and auto, we've got another roughly $10 billion, which reprices with a little less yield improvement than securities. reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)

text: On the variable-rate asset side, and to protect from down moves in rates, we hedge some of that with cash-flow swaps. And those typically roll off in any given quarter and get replaced over time.

text: So included in the cash flow hedges is an impact of cessation of BSBY as an alternative rate. If you recall, we took a charge in the fourth quarter of '23. text: In addition, we've got about $150 billion of received-fixed cash-flow hedges protecting us from short rate moves moving lower. text: So starting in the second half of 2025, we begin to get some additional NII tailwind, because the cash-flow hedges with lower fixed-rate legs, where we receive, those will begin to roll off and will likely replace those at higher current market rates at the time. text: Hi, there.

text: Brian, can you come back to your thoughts? You're talking about the consumer spending holding at 4% right now, obviously, down from the very strong levels of a year or two years ago. When you look out and you mentioned how you guys are thinking the economy troughs in the middle of next year, do you think you could hold that 4% consumer spend? Do you think your consumers will hold that 4% spending number? Or could it actually deteriorate from here?
reference:
Gerard Cassidy (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q3, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 19

text: I think, Gerard, one is the -- there's obviously external events, which could change the situation in the globe and change dramatically. reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 19

text: So embedded in our teams [Inaudible] team's economic projections is a return to the 2% target the end of '25. The rate structure comes down beginning in the middle of next year, but still stays around 4% at the end of '25.
reference:

Bank of America, Q3, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 19

text: And so given that the economy -- the inflation is coming down, the economies would still be growing then and getting back toward trend growth, I think it would hold steady. And so it's been pretty steady, the month -- August into September and October, at this 4.5%, 5% level. And that's kind of just people get paid more, they spend a little bit more and pricing goes up. And then you have the ebbs and flows within it, what they spend on.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 19

text: And right now, you've kind of seen all the adjustments that came through the pandemic into the last couple of years sort of a just out of the system. reference:

text: All that's kind of leveled out of the system, including a drop in fuel prices and an increase -- and basically, it's relatively bounce around about the same and they're spending about the same amount of money on gas that they spent last year. reference:

text: Very good. And then as a follow-up question, you guys gave us good detail on Slide 8 about the potential changes coming from Basel III end game, and you showed us, obviously, the organic capital generation. Can you share with us possibly some of the mitigation strategies you might use? And specifically, if you could touch upon these changes for the equity instruments, particularly in the alternative energy space. I guess they're going up from 100% RWAs to 400%.
reference:
Gerard Cassidy (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q3, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 20

text: Would that change your thinking in that line of business as we go forward, should they stay in the final rules?
reference:

Bank of America, Q3, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 20

text: So I think, number one, I think the first thing is there'll be -- at the end of November, the comments are due, there'll be comments by our company, by all the other companies, by industry participants, and then the staff at the Fed will have to sort through all that and think to what they all mean.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 20

text: And there'll be very rigorous points about our views of the wisdom of the changes, the need that changes, the balance of the changes, the double accounting that you've heard much about. That being said, it is a little puzzling that you see some of the RWA increases for mortgage loans or for these types of investments in the environmental and housing and other spaces, which is sort of counter the policy that we want to do it. Now what would happen is we'd have to adjust the pricing and it would become more expensive.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 21

text: It's been a great business for us. We continue to drive it. But ultimately, it have to go through the market. You have the equity cost go up by a fourfold increase to get the returns.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 21

text: And so think about a pricing model, just increasing the amount of equity we have to dedicate, therefore, we have to get returns on that. And so that would happen. It just seems a little counterintuitive that people would be doing that on a set of rules that, basically, after the financial crisis, Dodd-Frank put in a set of rules and said here's how you count the RWA, without much evidence that this is an issue for companies because the Volker rule and all the stuff that are having issues of write-downs or changes here. And so the idea going up four times seems odd to us from a public policy standpoint, and also absent any evidence that this is an issue for the banking system.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 21

text: Very good. Thank you very much, Brian.
reference:
Gerard Cassidy (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q3, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 21

text: We'll take our next question from Jim Mitchell with Seaport Global. Please go ahead. Your line is open.

text: OK. Great. Good morning. Alastair, at a conference a month ago, you noted that if the Fed is done, you think deposit pricing is close to its peak, and I think you kind of talked us through that a little bit today.

Jim Mitchell (Analyst)

text: Some of your peers have been more fearful of a potential future material repricing in consumer savings, for example, from greater competition or further outflows. reference:
Jim Mitchell (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q3, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 22

text: Yeah. I mean, Jim, one of the things that I think gives us some confidence around NII troughing and then growing in the back half of next year is if you think -- we've seen the last Fed hike or you believe that the last Fed hike is a month from now or two months from now. And at some point, deposit pricing is going to stop going up. And there'll be a natural link to that, that's pretty normal.
reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 22

text: And then what you see, if you look forward into the forward curve is we've actually got Fed cuts, three of them, in the forward curve for next year. So yes, we anticipate will be some lag. I don't think we're any different than anyone else in that regard. But we're just pointing out that as we get toward peak rates, we're getting closer now so we can begin to see the end of that in terms of the later innings at this point.
reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 22

text: And the other thing we always have to remind everyone of this is the deposits that we have are very relationship based. reference:

But fundamentally, we're just making a judgment that we're getting toward the top of the rate cycle here for Fed funds and then deposit pricing will sort out in the quarter or two following.
reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 22

text: All right. That's fair. reference:

Alastair Borthwick (CFO)

reference:

text: It's been slower this quarter. And I think it gives us a sense that we've got a more durable NII stream underneath.

Bank of America, Q3, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 35

text: And that always -- if you think back like in the oil and gas thing in the end of '15, '16, we put up all of this reserve that was pre-CECL and then end up bringing it back in because the cargos were very modest. So I think we feel very good about the original underwriting, but you also have -- because of our ratings integrity on the office part of the portfolio, we pushed a fairly significant amount through reappraisal and relook, and we have the CECL reserves. But importantly, the charge-offs are falling already.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 35

text: Got it. And one bigger picture question as you think about the Basel III and the opportunity to mitigate and optimize. Does a 15% ROE feel like a good aspiration for the company over time, Brian, through the cycle? I mean recognizing that's where you are already today. But as you factor in the potential for new rules, anything about that?
reference:
John McDonald (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q3, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 35

text: Yeah. So I think if we're doing on -- I think a simple way to think about it is we're doing on $194 million of capital, which we did it this quarter. And that is -- you need about another, say, $10 billion to put a buffer on the end state need, $10 billion to $11 billion-plus, 0.5%, which is our normal buffer without any mitigation.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 35

text: And that would hit the ROTC a bit. And we -- I'm sure we can figure out ways to price to get that back. But remember, we're different than everybody else, John, because we're actually sitting on this amount of capital today. And so we are getting a 15% return on it.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 36

text: So I don't want to -- don't take that as saying I agree with the rules, but saying we got to deal with the cards that are dealt to us. The rules say that you have to have $195 billion plus about $10 billion of cushion for -- and maybe a little bit more of cushion. But depending on -- for 50 basis points or so. But we're doing 15% today, so there will be a slight dilution to that number, but not something we couldn't make up, and that's before any mitigation ones.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 36

text: And there's always mitigation, you know that, you've been around this industry for a long time. So there's always mitigation to construct things, what you'll do, what you not do. And I fully expect there'll be modifications and rules which ought to help also. But I think the simple point is, we earned that amount of capital today, so it's not like some calculation I have to think through.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 36

text: It's right there today.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 36

text: That's good perspective. Thanks, Brian.
reference:
John McDonald (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q3, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 36

reference:

Dominant part of our balance sheet. I just sense that you were talking about each other, but maybe not.
reference:

reference:
Alastair Borthwick (CFO)

text: Hi. Good morning. My question was around deposit growth level and deposit growth you think you need from here. Should it be in line with loan growth? reference:
Manan Gosalia (Analyst)

Bank of America, Q3, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 40

text: So a couple of things. One, just broad based, we have a $1.9 trillion of deposits and $1 trillion of loans. So we have a tremendously high deposit base. But also, if you think about -- if you look at the Slide 5 or whatever, as we show the deposits by business.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)

text: In the banking business, Global Banking, I think 6 quarters, we've been relatively flat, so -- and starting to grow off of that. That is fully priced. And it's not like Corporate Treasury way around to -- talk to you about what you're paying in a noninterest-bearing percentage that has drifted down. The amount they hold in excess of that, part of that to pay fees has been relatively stable.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 40

text: And so we feel very good about that. If you look at wealth management. Basically, all the movement was made -- has been made pretty much to the higher rate environment, i.e., buying treasury securities directly. If you look at our wealth management business, the amount of short-term cash-oriented type investments, money market funds, etc, treasuries, etc, has gone from like $500 billion to $700 billion or $800 billion over the last several -- last couple of years.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 40

text: So that move is taking place. And then -- and so the rest of it is now in a relatively stable base. You can see those numbers. If you go to the consumer side, there's basically two or three things.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 41

text: One is, in the medium-income households plus or minus, you're seeing the slow spend down, even though they still have multiples of what they had pre-pandemic in our accounts. And even if that's a small part of the overall deposit base, there's still a slow trend where that's drifting down as all the things you read about go on. And the higher end part of that base, in a broad consumer base, they're actually below the pandemic by about 20%. And that's because they move the money into the market, and you can see that in some of the preferred category pricing.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 41

text: So where people think about checking and money markets in this, we think -- I always have thought about it a little more straightforward, which is transactional cash and investment cash. The investment cash has largely been resuited across the businesses. The transactional cash holds because it's money in motion moving every day.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 41

text: And for our consumer business, that's represented by the $0.5 trillion of checking account balance that you can see on the page, with some modest amounts in money markets and stuff that are carried as the cushion people have.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 41

text: And if they move the money in the market, they've moved it. And so we're watching consumer because there's a little more drifting there, and it's up $250 billion since pre-pandemic. And you're saying you have the dynamics of loans, student loan repayments starting, that's 1 million of our customers pay student loans. You have the dynamics of interest rate impacts on cash carry of loan balances, so that's higher.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 41

text: And that will sort out, but it takes a lot longer. That's across 37 million people, so it's -- the impact we'll have to sort through. And so we feel good about it.
reference:

text: But I think people look by category and this and that, you have to think about more how a customer, what in the business a consumer behaves. And what we've seen is them adjusting their behavior based on their household circumstances. And largely through the system and most of it coming a little bit slower in consumer just because of the natural question that they're -- if there are a lot of stimulus win in those accounts, what do I do with it over time, and now they're doing something.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 42

They come in at lower than that, mature up to that. We grow -- we have transactional banking business for all types of customers and we grow it irrespectively.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 42

text: That produces $2 trillion. You have a loan business to customers, that produces $1 trillion. And that difference then is a wonderful thing to have every day.
reference:

text: I appreciate it. Thank you.

text: Good morning. Welcome, and thank you for joining the call to review our third quarter results. reference:
Lee McEntire (Host)
Bank of America, Q3, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: Let me just remind you that we may make forward-looking statements and refer to non-GAAP financial measures during the call. Factors that may cause our actual results to materially differ from expectations are detailed in our earnings materials and our SEC filings that are available on the website.
reference:
Lee McEntire (Host)
Bank of America, Q3, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: Information about non-GAAP financial measures, including reconciliations to U.S. GAAP, can also be found in our earnings materials that are available on the website. So with that, Brian, take it away.
reference:
Lee McEntire (Host)
Bank of America, Q3, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: Thank you, Lee, and good morning, and thank all of you for joining us for our discussion of our third-quarter results. Bank of America continued to demonstrate strength this quarter in an economy that continued to be stable, albeit with slower growth and falling inflation.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: So many of you have asked me from time to time, what do we see in our own consumer customer base? As we talked about many times, our consumer payments is an indicator of activity. Those payments were up 4% to 5% year-over-year for the quarter in the total money those consumers moved in the economy.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: The pace of year-to-year money movement has been steady since late summer this year, after having fallen in the spring and early summer. This growth in consumer payments continues into October.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: This activity is consistent with how customers are spending money in the 2016 to 2019 time frame, when the economy was growing and inflation was under control. This report has not meant to gainsay that consumers are wary of the cost of living, worried about higher rates and other matters. But overall, activity is fine.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: Unemployment is low and wage growth is steady, both of which bode both for the consumer overall and for consumer asset quality.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: With respect to what we see in our commercial businesses, it is consistent with the lower growth economy. Line of credit usage rates remain lower than pre-pandemic levels. This does not surprise us, with the dramatic increase in the cost of borrowing for small and medium-sized businesses.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: They aren't being indolent. They want to grow. They are simply being more careful and worry if final demand will hold. Therefore, they are being cost conscious across the board.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: So how did Bank of America do against this backdrop? At Bank of America, our commitment to responsible growth remains unwavering, and this quarter is another illustration of that. We grew, and we did it the right way.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: In the third quarter, Bank of America generated $25.5 billion in revenue and earned $6.9 billion net income after tax. Year-to-date, we've generated net income of just over $20 billion.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Four quarters ago, we called that a bottom would occur in our net interest income in the second quarter of 2024. Even with the rate environment that has bounced around quite a bit since we said that, we got it right. As we expected then, NII indeed troughed in the quarter 2. NII grew 2% this quarter. And as Alastair will note later, we expect NII to grow again in quarter 4, even as the market expects 2 more rate cuts in quarter 4.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: This quarter, we saw a healthy revenue growth in our Wealth and Investment Management business and in our Global Markets businesses. We returned $5.6 billion of capital to shareholders, while also supporting the needs of our clients. So with that brief overview, let's dive into Slide 2.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Earnings per share came in at $0.81 this quarter. At $25.5 billion in revenue, we grew modestly from the third quarter '23 as improvement in noninterest income more than offset a year-over-year decline in net interest income.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Fees grew 5% year-over-year and represented 45% of total revenue. The strong year-over-year fee performance was led by a 15% improvement in investment and brokerage services, mostly in our Global Wealth Management business. We also grew investment banking fees 18% year-over-year.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Sales and trading revenue increased 12% year-over-year. In aggregate, these market-related revenue streams rose an impressive 13% year-over-year. Our total expense in the company increased 4%. You can attribute most of the year-over-year expense growth to these market-related areas. Overall, a good job by the team.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: On asset quality, A few quarters ago, we told you that consumer credit losses will go down this quarter given delinquency trends we had seen at the time. We also told you that office losses would be lower. Both of these proved true again this quarter.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Good asset quality resulted in net charge-offs and provision expense for this quarter at $1.5 billion, which was unchanged from last quarter. Our performance is partly attributable to the diversity and balance of the company. A little more than half earnings come from our Consumer and GWIM businesses, serving people, and the other half come through from our Global Banking and Markets businesses, serving companies and institutional investors.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q3, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: So let's turn to see how we grew organically this quarter. We are now on Slide 3. Our organic growth has been driven by a continued focus on customers’ and clients’ experience throughout all our businesses.

text: Let's move to discussion of full year 2023 earnings. We reported net income of $26.5 billion after tax, which includes $2.8 billion after tax for notable Quarter 4 items. Adjusted for those items, the adjusted net income was $29.3 billion after tax.

text: The year 2023 was characterized by a record organic customer activity, record digital customer engagement levels, and satisfaction scores; strong but slowing NII during the course of the year; strong sales and trading up 7% year over year; operating leverage reflected good expense discipline; solid asset quality; and a strong capital liquidity position. text: Adjusted full year revenue grew 5% on a back of 9% NII improvement and strong asset management fees and sales and trading results. text: Also, note that the blended cash and securities yield continued to rise and remained about 170 basis points above the rate we pay for deposits. The replacement of these lower-earning assets into higher-yielding assets continues to provide an ongoing benefit and support to NII.

text: From a valuation perspective, given the reduced balance and the longer-term interest rate reductions we've seen in the fourth quarter, we experienced an improvement of more than $30 billion in the valuation of the hold-to-maturity securities.

Alastair Borthwick (CFO)
Bank of America, Q4, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

text: So, let's turn our focus to NII performance using Slide 10. And a strong finish to the year helped us report 57.5 billion in NII on a fully tax equivalent basis for the full year of 2023. text: And as we look forward, given that we've got one last day of interest in the first quarter, and that's worth about 125 million to 150 million. reference:
Mike Mayo (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q4, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 24

text: So, I think, you know, our research team, you know, has rate cuts in next year and has a soft landing, as you referenced, Mike. So, that's it. As you see the customers today, as I said earlier, the year-to-year spending growth in the fourth quarter versus last year's fourth quarter or in the first quarter so far versus the first part of last year is a 4% to 5% rate in movement of money. And that was across $4 trillion plus out of the consumer accounts and Bank of America into the economy.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q4, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 24

text: That 4% to 5% is similar to what it was in '17, '18, '19 when the Fed rose -- took rates up. Inflation was under control, and economy is growing at, you know, 2% -- 1.5%, 2%, 2.5%. And so, the spending level should sustain an economy, albeit our core prediction, as it's slowing down from a higher growth rate in the third quarter, 4.5, 5, or whatever it was, down to a percent or something like that in the first couple of quarters next year.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q4, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 24

text: But we see the consumer activity indicating that they're still in the game, they're still spending money where they spend. It's a little different, more in services and going out in restaurants and experiences, and less on goods at retail.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q4, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 25

text: They're employed. You know, if you look at the estimates by any of you, any of your economists, the unemployment rate projected is, you know, really a modest deterioration from here. And most of them in the core base case. Our reserves are actually set at almost a 5% unemployment rate by the end of this year, to give you a sense. So, that's good news.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q4, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 25

text: They're using their credit responsibly. Much is made of, you know, higher credit card balances, but on the size of the economy and the size -- you know, people forgetting that, you know, economy is a lot bigger than it was in '19 because of the inflation and everything. And as a percentage, we don't see any stress there. We see a normalization of that credit.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q4, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 25

text: So, they're working, they're getting paid. They have balances in their accounts. They have access to credit. They've locked in good rates on their mortgages. And they're employed. It's -- we feel it's good. So, we think the soft landing is of course thesis, and our internal data supports what our research team sees. And they get -- you know, they see it also through our institute.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q4, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 25

text: And then, just as far as controlling what you can control in terms of expenses and headcount, tech investments, and maybe throw in AI as part of that, what sort of extra efficiencies can you achieve through AI, tech, and other initiatives? You squeezed a lot out over the last decade plus. What's left to go?
reference:
Mike Mayo (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q4, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 25

text: You know, there's always more to go. So, I think we've got lined up -- if you take what we're doing this year and next year, meaning '24, '25, and rolling in 26, it's a couple of billion dollars plus, which helps us to the dynamic. Erica was talking about avoiding growth in expenses, keeping it below inflation, because you think of us as rolling that expense taken out back into good things.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q4, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 25

text: This year will be, I think, $3.8 billion on technology initiatives. That's up from '21 to '22 by 500 million or more, and then sort of flattish '22 to '23. They're being applied in different ways. We added relationship managers across the board. We keep opening the branches.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q4, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 26

text: We're largely through the rehab of the branches that we're keeping. And these are all spending to grow, and that's what you're seeing. So, net new checking accounts, 600,000 for the year. That's 20 straight quarters of net checking account growth.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q4, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 26

text: All good core account flows into the asset management business, 80 billion or more. In our Merrill Edge program, the advertising has driven the business. We have 10% more customers. And those customers, which is 300,000 to 400,000 customers, added in the last 12 months. Those customers bring an average opening balance of $80,000 to $100,000. To give you a sense, they're not small accounts. That's good. So, we're just investing.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q4, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 26

text: But there's a thousand levers. None of them are simple. But even this year, when we said we've got to get the headcount growth back in -- you know, back in an alliance after the great resignation '22 and we had to hire fast, we went from 218,000 people in January down to 212,900 at the end of the year.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q4, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 26

text: And in that, we're rolling over teammates from one business to another business where we need help and retraining people and reskilling people. And as AI comes in, and to the extent that we can deploy it, deploy it wisely, it'll allow us to redeploy people.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q4, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 26

text: And even with our very low turnover rate, which is 7% for year '23 and actually down from 12% in the year '22, and I think 6% in the fourth quarter, you know, we still can manage headcount down just by not hiring people because that gives us an opportunity. We hired 15,000 people this year. So, we hire -- we can always hire a little less if we see the efficiencies coming through and redeploy the people we have.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q4, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 26

text: All right. Thank you.
reference:
Mike Mayo (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q4, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 27

reference:

reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q4, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 27

text: They fundamentally moved up. That was deploying more balance sheet, you know, a little bit more capital inherently, but not a lot. They're not taking a lot of risks. They made money every trading day in '23 again, I think.
reference:

Bank of America, Q4, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 28

text: And so, they do a great job of serving the clients. So, I don't think it was a big capital, you know, a massive amount of capital. They get the capital they need. You know, they have the balance sheet and the, you know, the risk appetite they need.
reference:

Bank of America, Q4, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 28

text: But we're continuing to put money toward that business because they've proven to be successful. We gave them the balance sheet a few years ago, and they were able to deploy. More broadly, you know, we pay out the dividend. We then have a bunch of capital today.

text: We meet the standards as best. As Alastair said, we can define from the rule, and we'll see what the final rule looks like when it comes out. But right now, the $194 billion of CET1 is the level of notional CET1. We'd have to meet the RWA inflation.
reference:

text: I'm not saying it's a good rule, I'm just saying we make the math work. And so, from now on, we can basically deploy capital to to the dividend payment, a couple billion dollars a quarter, and then everything above that will go to support business growth if we have it, build a little bit of cushion. We need to build over some period of time to meet these new rules if they come through. And then, share buybacks, which we bought 800 million or so last quarter, and you'd expect that to keep ticking up.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q4, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 28

text: OK. That's helpful. And then, you did mention that trading or markets is off to a good start so far this year. Obviously, just a handful of days. But any color around that? But I think you can use the '23 numbers as a baseline starting point. And then for the first quarter, I'd just apply sort of a typical kind of seasonality.

Bank of America, Q4, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 29

text: OK. Thank you very much.
reference:

Bank of America, Q4, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 29

And the question is, you know, sort of when is the clarity.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q4, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 29

text: And you're seeing some stuff get done. And with stability and rates, you'd expect that to kick back up. You expect it to move back in those levels. And we have actually been gaining share over the last few quarters as the market's gone down around as we held our relative position grew it.
reference:

reference:
Glenn Schorr (Analyst)
Bank of America, Q4, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 30

text: So, is that a good thing, or is that a risk? And maybe the answer lies within how much of those excess deposits are sitting in all these new accounts that you've opened versus just cash from sitting around in existing clients that maybe waiting to be deployed. I hope that question is clear.

text: So, Glenn, you make me had deja vu because, basically, I think you would have asked this question the first quarter of '23, too, on the theory that this was all going to run off. If you strung that line out that we're still above that line, let's just say that. And now we're turning and growing.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q4, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 30

Bank of America, Q4, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 30

text: Now, if you look at the underlying dynamics, you think about the different clients. And they've been relatively stable now for, I don't know, five, six months, I think.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q4, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 31

text: If you look at the wholesale banking, what's happened is they came -- you know, they shot up, came down after the pandemic. And then they've been growing back. And they're actually stronger because just the activity is picked up in a stabilization of line usage has -- shows that the [Inaudible] rates have done that.
reference:
Brian Moynihan (CEO)
Bank of America, Q4, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 31

text: And is there -- is it still bouncing around a little bit in consumer? Yeah, they're $950 billion more or less on a given day. But it's -- you know, it's stabilized and been relatively consistent for the last four, six, eight weeks. But that's got to settle in and then you grow out from there.
reference:

Bank of America, Q4, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 31

reference:

You know, so the money that's moved is moved. And we pay higher rates for very high balances and stuff like that, especially in like the Merrill Edge platform. So, a lot of that dynamic is for the system right now, for lack of a better term.

Quickie on reserves is with a pretty solid economy, resilient U.S. consumer, your NPLs are down, you have a lot of reserves, the question is, what are the signposts that you or we should be looking for to know when you've added enough, when we're stable enough point in time, and you actually start funding charge-offs from reserves and not adding? reference:

Brian Moynihan (CEO)

reference:

reference:

text: Thanks. And then, just one more clarifying question on NII. So, in this scenario with the six rate cuts, can you help us understand how you expect the deposit mix to migrate? reference:

But if you think about the current environment, what's driving is different. Our revenue growth is growing at twice that rate plus and the expense growth is growing close to that number. But when you get to higher growth rates, especially where it's coming from Wealth Management business, market-based business, businesses in investment banking, it attaches a higher sort of instantaneous expense. text: One of the risks -- I mean, when you guys sit down at night, everything is going well. What do you talk about is what curveballs do we have to watch out for? text: Well, you have wars and hopefully, a resolution of one that's just happening as we speak. But you have wars, you have trade wars, et cetera, that bothers. text: But if you think about it, Gerard, just to be clear, we've seen a 15-year run from after the pandemic -- excuse me, after the financial -- global financial crisis or more, year run where you've seen constantly improving our credit statistics that then interrupted in the pandemic a little bit and then because the stimulus dropped down again and now it's back to normal, but that's a long-term trend.
reference:

text: So it's not complacency. It's just that how much leverage is building up in the system that there will be difficulties with, either at the household level, at the company level. reference:

text: So we worry about all those things and the federal debt levels and the pinch that will come out of state and federal spending if they have to -- they need to slow down the growth. And that's why the stress testing, quite frankly, is a good thing because it makes you think about the parade of horribles happening, even though they don't happen and make sure that you are positioned to survive them.
